deliberation: I checked for idioms, anthropomorphisms, and symbolic elements. The valley of bones is part of the vision world and is described straightforwardly. The clear figurative expression is the anthropomorphic idiom "the hand of YHWH was upon me," a conventional metaphor for overpowering divine influence on the prophet.

divine empowerment of a prophet
theological / prophetic experience
vehicle: a human hand as an instrument of power and control
ground: forceful control and guidance exerted by a stronger agent over another
the feeling of being grasped and moved by another’s power
agency and control dynamics
posture: Ezekiel reports this as a conventional image rather than a literal physical hand
reverent acknowledgment of God’s initiative using human bodily imagery accepted by the audience
prophetic formulaic language
instances.explanation: Anthropomorphic idiom: God’s "hand" metaphorically represents His powerful, controlling presence upon the prophet.

deliberation: I looked for hyperbole or symbolic labels. The verse simply describes being led around and observing very many very dry bones. The intensifiers for number and dryness function descriptively within the vision rather than as distinct figurative expressions.

I examined the vocative "son of man" and the question about bones living. The question is rhetorical but not itself metaphorical. The expression "בן־אָדָם" is a conventional idiom/metonymy highlighting Ezekiel’s mortal, human status.

a human prophet in contrast to God
humanity / anthropology
ground: sharing the nature and limitations of human beings (mortality, frailty)
emphasis on humanness over against God’s transcendence
creaturely dependence
posture: God addresses Ezekiel with a humbling title accepted as a conventional prophetic vocative
Ezekiel and the audience understand this as highlighting human limitation, not as a literal genealogical statement
reverential, asymmetrical speaker–addressee relationship
instances.explanation: "Son of man" is an idiomatic metonymy for a mere human, underscoring Ezekiel’s mortality and smallness before God.

deliberation: I considered whether the bones are already explicitly equated with Israel here (that comes in v.11). In this verse the clear device is addressing inanimate, skeletal remains as hearers of God’s word, which is personification and participates in the larger metaphor of Israel as dead bones.

instances.english_text: O dry bones, hear the word of GOD!

the covenant people in hopeless exile
national-spiritual condition

lifeless skeletal remains personified as listeners
ground: complete lifelessness and inability contrasted with God’s life-giving word
the people’s utter hopelessness and incapacity apart from divine intervention
death vs. life contrast
posture: the prophet speaks within the vision as if the bones were conscious hearers
the audience understands this as a visionary image, not a literal sermon to bones
prophetic dramatization accepted as symbolic for Israel’s condition
instances.explanation: The lifeless bones are addressed as if they can hear God’s word, personifying them and contributing to the larger metaphor of Israel as a dead, exiled community.

deliberation: I examined whether "breath" (רוּחַ) functions only within the vision or already as a metaphor for God’s life-giving Spirit to Israel. Given the context of death-to-life and later "my Spirit" in v.14, this verse participates in that life-giving metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה אֲנִי מֵבִיא בָכֶם רוּחַ וִחְיִיתֶם
instances.english_text: I will cause breath to enter you and you shall live again
target: the restoration of Israel’s communal life from exile and despair
national-spiritual renewal of the people
corporate salvation / restoration
vehicle: breath entering lifeless bones and reviving them
ground: life depends on breath just as Israel’s future depends on God’s life-giving action
transition from death to vitality
dependence on an animating source
posture: God speaks in visionary terms that the audience recognizes as symbolizing His life-giving Spirit
the prophet accepts this concrete image as expressing an abstract restoration
prophetic promise framed in corporeal imagery
instances.explanation: The entry of "breath" into bones stands as a concrete metaphor for God’s life-giving action restoring Israel from its death-like exile.

deliberation: I checked whether the anatomical rebuilding (sinews, flesh, skin) introduced additional metaphors beyond the already established resurrection image. Here the language functions as detailed description within the same visionary picture, without new discrete figurative expressions.

I assessed whether "sound" and "rattling" were hyperbolic or symbolic. They describe the visionary process of bones reassembling and do not introduce a new metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond the ongoing scene.
The verse continues the stepwise description of bodily restoration within the vision. No added figurative labels or anthropomorphisms appear beyond the ongoing vision of reconstituted bodies.

I looked for personification and any merism. The "breath" (רוּחַ) is addressed and commanded as an agent, which is personification. The phrase "from the four winds" is a conventional compass merism for "from all directions / the whole world."

instances.hebrew_text: הִנָּבֵא אֶל־הָרוּחַ ... כֹּה־אָמַר ... מֵאַרְבַּע רוּחוֹת בֹּאִי הָרוּחַ וּפְחִי בַּהֲרוּגִים הָאֵלֶּה

divine animating power
spiritual / theological reality
vehicle: breath/wind addressed as if a personal agent summoned from the four winds to revive the dead
an animate, responsive wind acting on command

God’s Spirit operates like a free, dynamic wind that gives life
agency and responsiveness attributed to an impersonal element
posture: the prophet treats the breath/wind as a personal addressee within the vision
the audience recognizes this as symbolic personification of God’s Spirit, not literal conversation with air
prophetic dramatization of divine agency
instances.explanation: The "breath" or wind is personified—addressed and commanded—to act as God’s life-giving agent, embodying His Spirit’s reviving power.

instances.english_text: from the four winds

posture: the prophet uses a conventional merism without explaining it
the audience understands "four winds" as a way to say "from all directions"
shared cosmological idiom
instances.explanation: "From the four winds" is a merism: the four compass winds collectively express totality, indicating God summons life-giving breath from every direction.

deliberation: I checked whether "a vast army" was metaphorical or simply descriptive within the vision. Here it naturally describes the multitude of revived figures in martial formation in the vision, without a separate figurative expression in the wording itself.

This verse contains the explicit interpretation of the bones, plus the self-description of the people. I identified: (1) a direct metaphor equating the bones with "the whole house of Israel"; (2) a metaphor in "our bones are dried up" for utter hopelessness; and (3) an idiomatic expression "we are cut off" for being doomed.

instances.english_text: these bones are the whole House of Israel
target: the whole house of Israel in exile
the covenant people as a corporate entity
national community
vehicle: a valley full of desiccated bones
ground: Israel’s corporate condition is as hopeless and lifeless as a heap of dry bones
both are devoid of visible vitality or prospects
extreme deprivation / death-like state
posture: God explicitly identifies the visionary image with Israel, signaling it as a metaphorical representation
the prophet and audience are invited to reinterpret the whole vision through this equation
authoritative divine interpretation of the symbolic picture
instances.explanation: God directly equates the visionary bones with Israel, making the bones an explicit metaphor (and symbolic image) for the exiled nation’s death-like condition.

instances.english_text: Our bones are dried up
target: the inner strength and vitality of the exiled people
the community’s morale and capacity to hope
psychological-spiritual state
ground: dry bones signify exhaustion and irreversible loss of life
the people feel completely depleted and beyond recovery
permanent, brittle weakness
posture: Israel voices its condition using bodily imagery for inner despair
this complaint is accepted as figurative self-description, not a literal medical state
lament language drawing on somatic metaphor
instances.explanation: The people describe their condition using bodily imagery: "our bones are dried" metaphorically expresses total exhaustion and loss of vitality.

instances.english_text: we are cut off [for ourselves]
target: Israel’s future prospects and covenant status
the community’s ongoing existence and connection to God
national destiny

the people see themselves as severed from life, land, and covenant
finality and isolation
posture: the phrase functions as an idiomatic lament for being doomed
speaker uses the cutting image conventionally to voice despair
figurative self-diagnosis rather than a literal physical cutting
instances.explanation: The complaint "we are cut off" is an idiomatic metaphor for being utterly doomed and severed from hope and covenantal life.

deliberation: I considered whether "open your graves" is literal resurrection or figurative for return from exile. In context (especially vv.11, 14, 21), "graves" metaphorically depict the lands/exile as death, and coming up from graves depicts national restoration.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה אֲנִי פֹתֵחַ אֶת־קִבְרוֹתֵיכֶם וְהַעֲלֵיתִי אֶתְכֶם מִקִּבְרוֹתֵיכֶם עַמִּי

return to the land is like resurrection from death
radical reversal from final loss to renewed life

the audience is led to understand grave-opening figuratively in historical-theological terms
prophetic promise using eschatological-resurrection imagery
instances.explanation: Opening graves and bringing the people up is a resurrection metaphor for ending exile and restoring Israel to its land.

deliberation: This verse repeats the grave-opening image as the basis for recognizing YHWH. It is the same resurrection metaphor of v.12, applied again as the sign of God’s identity.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּפִתְחִי אֶת־קִבְרוֹתֵיכֶם וּבְהַעֲלוֹתִי אֶתְכֶם מִקִּבְרוֹתֵיכֶם עַמִּי

recognition of YHWH via historical deliverance

knowing God through a death-to-life kind of deliverance

audience is invited to interpret national events through resurrection imagery
didactic reuse of established metaphor
instances.explanation: Again, opening graves and raising the people is a metaphor describing the dramatic national restoration by which Israel will recognize YHWH.

deliberation: I focused on "I will put My spirit/breath in you" and its relation to living on the land. This clearly extends the life-from-death metaphor: God’s own Spirit is portrayed as the inner breath reviving Israel as a people.

instances.english_text: I will put My breath/Spirit into you and you shall live again
target: Israel’s inward renewal and empowerment by God
the restored spiritual and communal life of the people
inner transformation of the nation
vehicle: God’s own Spirit as breath put inside bodies
ground: as breath animates a body, God’s Spirit animates and sustains the community
life and vitality depend on an internal, invisible force
intimate indwelling as condition for life
posture: God uses concrete bodily imagery to communicate an inward, spiritual reality
the audience is expected to see beyond the literal to divine indwelling power
prophetic promise framed with embodied metaphor
instances.explanation: God’s "Spirit" is described as breath placed within Israel, a metaphor for His life-giving, indwelling power restoring them to true life.

deliberation: I considered the formula "the word of YHWH came to me." This standard prophetic expression personifies the divine word as if it were an entity that travels and arrives to the prophet.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me

prophetic inspiration/revelation

audience understands this as idiomatic for receiving revelation, not literal movement of a physical object
conventional prophetic diction
instances.explanation: The divine "word" is personified as if it travels and arrives, a conventional idiom for the prophet’s reception of revelation.

deliberation: I examined the tribal names and the sticks. The sticks are physical objects at this stage, but the names on them already function metonymically: Judah stands for the southern kingdom, Joseph/Ephraim for the northern kingdom.

instances.english_text: “Of Judah and the Israelites associated with him”

the political entity centered on Judah
national-political collective
vehicle: the name "Judah" with "the Israelites his companions"
one leading tribe with attached companions
ground: Judah as the dominant tribe stands for the whole southern kingdom
naming the tribe implies the larger political unit it leads
part-for-whole reference
posture: God uses tribal nomenclature as a shorthand for the geopolitical entity
the audience recognizes this as conventional metonymy for the southern kingdom
prophetic naming practice
instances.explanation: "Judah" with his companions is a tribal metonymy for the entire southern kingdom allied with Judah.

instances.hebrew_text: לְיוֹסֵף עֵץ אֶפְרַיִם וְכׇל־בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל חֲבֵרָו

national-political collective

prominent ancestor/tribe representing the whole north
ground: Joseph/Ephraim as leading figures/tribes represent the entire northern confederation
the ancestor or leading tribe stands in for the whole people descended from or led by them
founder/leader-for-group metonymy
posture: God invokes Joseph/Ephraim as accepted shorthand for the northern kingdom
the audience hears these names as political-religious designations, not just genealogical labels
prophetic use of ancestral metonymy
instances.explanation: “Joseph” / “Ephraim” functions metonymically for the northern kingdom and its allied tribes.

deliberation: I assessed whether bringing two sticks together is purely an enacted sign or also verbal metaphor. Here "they shall become one stick in your hand" already states, in verbal form, a unification image whose referent (one nation) is clarified in vv.19–22.

instances.english_text: so that they become one stick, joined together in your hand
target: the future political and spiritual unity of Israel and Judah
reunification of the divided kingdoms into a single nation
national-political condition
vehicle: two separate sticks becoming one in the prophet’s hand
fusion of distinct pieces of wood held together
ground: distinct groups losing their separation and functioning as a single entity
unity under a single controlling hand/authority
overcoming division by becoming one
posture: God commands a symbolic action that visually enacts the metaphor of unity
the language about one stick prepares the audience to receive the later explanation of one nation
prophetic sign-act with explicit unifying imagery
instances.explanation: The two sticks becoming one in Ezekiel’s hand metaphorically depict the future unification of the formerly divided kingdoms into a single people.

deliberation: This verse records the anticipated question about the sign-act: "What are these to you?" The wording itself is literal; the figurative significance resides in the previously mentioned sticks, not in a new figurative expression here.

Here God interprets the sign: the sticks explicitly stand for the two houses and their unification. I distinguish (1) the stick of Joseph/Ephraim as representing the northern tribes, and (2) the composite "one stick" in God’s hand as representing a unified people under His rule.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶת־עֵץ יוֹסֵף אֲשֶׁר בְּיַד־אֶפְרַיִם וְשִׁבְטֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל חֲבֵרָו
instances.english_text: the stick of Joseph—which is in the hand of Ephraim—and of the tribes of Israel associated with him
target: the northern kingdom and its constituent tribes
the collective of Israel’s northern tribes
political-religious community

a piece of wood held in someone’s hand
ground: one simple object can stand in for a complex group it is labeled with or held by
the stick’s unity mirrors the political unity of the tribes it represents
representational symbolism (token for group)
posture: God explicitly uses a labeled stick as a symbolic vehicle for an entire kingdom
the prophet and audience are invited to accept a concrete object as a stand-in for a large community
interpreted sign-act employing metonymic symbol
instances.explanation: The labeled "stick of Joseph" serves as a symbolic stand-in (metonymic metaphor) for the entire northern kingdom and its tribes.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתִּי אוֹתָם עָלָיו אֶת־עֵץ יְהוּדָה וְעָשִׂיתִם לְעֵץ אֶחָד וְהָיוּ אֶחָד בְּיָדִי
instances.english_text: I will place the stick of Judah upon it and make them into one stick; they shall be joined in My hand
target: the future unified people of God formed from Judah and the northern tribes
a single, reunited nation under divine sovereignty
corporate Israel
vehicle: two sticks joined into one stick held in God’s hand
a composite piece of wood under a single grip
ground: formerly separate entities become a single unit under one controlling hand
God’s hand holding one stick reflects His rule over a unified nation
unity and possession expressed through a single object
posture: God interprets the joined stick as representing the joined people in His hand
audience is guided to read the visible sign as a metaphor for political-spiritual unity
didactic metaphor of unification and divine lordship
instances.explanation: The two labeled sticks fused into one in God’s hand metaphorically represent the reunification of Judah and Israel under God’s singular rule.

deliberation: This verse instructs Ezekiel to display the inscribed sticks. The figurative value resides in what has already been explained about them; the wording here is straightforwardly procedural.

I checked whether "from among the nations" and "from every side" formed a merism or metaphor. They naturally describe geographic dispersion and regathering; they are standard spatial expressions and not clearly elevated to a separate figurative device here.
The promise of making them one nation with one king is conceptually related to earlier imagery (one stick), but the verse itself speaks in literal political terms with no new figurative expression.

I looked at "defile themselves" with idols and the covenant formula. The covenant formula is standard. The verb "defile" imports ritual impurity language into the moral/Idolatrous sphere, which is a pervasive moral-ritual metaphor in the Hebrew Bible.

instances.hebrew_text: וְלֹא יִטַּמְּאוּ עוֹד בְּגִלּוּלֵיהֶם וּבְשִׁקּוּצֵיהֶם וּבְכֹל פִּשְׁעֵיהֶם
instances.english_text: Nor shall they ever again defile themselves by their fetishes and their abhorrent things, and by their other transgressions
target: Israel’s moral and spiritual corruption through idolatry and sin
their guilty standing and polluted relationship with God
ethical-spiritual condition
vehicle: ritual or physical defilement (becoming unclean) through contact with abominations
impurity that stains a person or object
ground: sin and idolatry damage and pollute a person in relation to God as ritual impurity does in cultic terms
both require cleansing to restore acceptable status
contamination and exclusion imagery
posture: God uses cultic impurity language to describe moral idolatry
the audience is expected to map familiar ritual categories onto ethical behavior
conceptual metaphor of sin-as-impurity
instances.explanation: The verse uses impurity language ("defile themselves") metaphorically for moral and spiritual corruption through idolatry and transgression.

deliberation: This verse contains the prominent shepherd metaphor: "one shepherd" for all of them. "My servant David" may be metonymic for a future Davidic ruler, but the clearest figurative expression is king-as-shepherd.

instances.english_text: there shall be one shepherd for all of them
target: the future Davidic king/ruler over united Israel
political-spiritual leadership of the nation
governance / kingship
vehicle: a single shepherd caring for a flock
shepherding role guiding, feeding, and protecting sheep
ground: a shepherd guides, protects, and provides for a vulnerable flock just as a good king leads and cares for his people
both involve personal oversight and responsibility for the group’s well-being
guidance, protection, and unity under one leader
posture: God deliberately frames kingship in pastoral terms to stress care rather than domination
the audience, familiar with shepherd-kings, understands this as a leadership metaphor
prophetic idealization of monarchy using agrarian imagery
instances.explanation: The one future king is portrayed metaphorically as a single shepherd caring for all the people, highlighting protective and guiding aspects of his rule.

deliberation: I considered "forever" (עוֹלָם) for hyperbole and the reference to "David my servant." The enduring language is covenantal and debated, but "David my servant" most naturally functions as a metonymy: the name of the founding king representing the ongoing Davidic ruler/line.

instances.english_text: with My servant David as their prince for all time
target: the eschatological or ongoing Davidic ruler over restored Israel
the ruling figure from David’s line
dynastic kingship
vehicle: the personal name "David" used with "my servant" as a present/future prince
the historical founder of the dynasty
ground: the founding king represents and embodies the dynasty that continues his rule
invoking David’s name signals the type and legitimacy of the expected ruler
founder-for-dynasty metonymy
posture: God speaks of "David" as an enduring princely presence, prompting the audience to think of David’s line rather than strictly the historical individual
hearers versed in royal theology would grasp the dynastic implication
prophetic use of ancestral royal name as a symbol of the promised ruler
instances.explanation: “David my servant” functions as a dynastic metonymy: the founding king’s name stands for the enduring Davidic ruler who will be prince over the restored people.

deliberation: I checked "covenant of peace" and "cut a covenant." The phrase "cut a covenant" (כרת ברית) is a fixed idiom rooted in sacrificial practice, functioning figuratively as the standard way to speak of making a binding agreement.

instances.english_text: I will make (lit. cut) a covenant of peace with them
target: God’s establishment of a binding, enduring relationship of peace with His people
the act of entering a formal covenant
relational-legal transaction
vehicle: a ritual act of cutting associated with treaty-making
ground: ancient covenants were ratified by cutting animals, so "cut" came to mean "make a covenant"
the physical act represents the seriousness and binding nature of the agreement
ritual action as shorthand for a legal-relational act
posture: God uses a culturally fixed idiom whose literal sacrificial origins are backgrounded
audience understands "cut a covenant" as formulaic for establishing a treaty-like bond
conventional legal-theological phrase
instances.explanation: “Cut a covenant” is an idiom that figuratively uses the act of cutting (from sacrificial ratification) to denote the making of a formal, binding covenant.

deliberation: I focused on "my dwelling (mishkani) shall be over them" and the covenant formula. The dwelling language casts God’s presence in spatial, tabernacle terms—a metaphor for His protective, intimate presence among the people.

instances.english_text: My Presence/dwelling shall rest over them
target: God’s ongoing, protective, relational presence with His people
His covenantal nearness and oversight
theological reality of divine indwelling
vehicle: a dwelling/tabernacle resting over a people
a physical structure situated above/among inhabitants
ground: a dwelling denotes settled presence, accessibility, and protection
God’s continuous presence is like a shelter or tabernacle over the community
stability, nearness, and covering
posture: God uses cultic-spatial imagery to convey relational closeness
the audience maps the tabernacle/Temple concept onto the idea of God living with them
sacred-architecture metaphor applied to covenant presence
instances.explanation: God’s "dwelling" being over the people is a spatial-temple metaphor for His settled, protective presence in their midst.

deliberation: I examined "sanctify Israel" and "when My sanctuary is among them." Both draw on cultic language, but here they describe straightforwardly that God sets Israel apart and that His sanctuary will be in their midst; no additional distinct figurative turn beyond standard cultic-theological diction emerges in this wording.
